slides.mascot_explanation: This is the super cool trick! When we multiply any number by 10, we just take that number and add a zero right after it! So, if we have 7 and we multiply by 10, it becomes 70! If we have 9, it becomes 90! Isn't that neat?

slides.prompt: Complete the 10s table from 10x1 to 10x10. Then do a speed round with flash cards: 2s, 5s, and 10s mixed together. How many can you answer correctly?
slides.mascot_explanation: Ready for a fun game? Let's see if we can fill out our whole 10s table all the way to 10 times 10. Then, we'll use the flash cards with 2s, 5s, and 10s to see how fast we can answer. You can do it!

slides.text: 'The 10s are the easiest multiplication table because of the zero pattern! Now you know three whole tables: 2s, 5s, and 10s. That is 30 facts!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child state all 10s multiplication facts from 10x1 through 10x10 quickly and explain the zero pattern?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You finished the 10s table, and you learned that adding a zero makes the number super big! Now you know the 2s, 5s, and 10s tables – that's 30 multiplication facts! You're a math superstar!

parent_notes: The 10s multiplication table is a gift to young mathematicians because the pattern is so clear and consistent. This is rooted in our base-10 number system — multiplying by 10 shifts all digits one place to the left, which visually means adding a zero. The child does not need to understand place value theory; the pattern itself is sufficient. What is pedagogically powerful is that the child now knows three complete multiplication tables (2s, 5s, 10s), which covers 30 of the 100 basic multiplication facts. Combined with the commutative property (3x5 = 5x3), the child actually knows even more. Celebrate this progress — they are building mathematical confidence.

title: The Five Senses — Sense of Smell Experiments
description: Building on the sensorial smelling bottles work, the child conducts experiments about smell: testing whether smell affects taste, exploring scent memory, and discovering how the nose and brain work together.
instructions:
1. 'You explored smelling bottles today in sensorial. Now let's do EXPERIMENTS with smell!'
2. Experiment 1: Smell and Taste Connection. Hold your nose and eat a jelly bean. 'Can you tell the flavor?' Release nose. 'Now can you?' (Taste and smell work together!)
3. Experiment 2: Scent Memory. Smell three items (cinnamon, lemon, vanilla). Close eyes. Parent holds one near. 'Which one is it?'
4. Experiment 3: Scent Intensity. Smell a scented item from far away, then close. 'Is the smell stronger closer or farther?'
5. Record findings in science journal.

slides.heading: Smell Experiments
slides.subheading: How Smell and Taste Work Together
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Smell Experiments," and it's going to show us how our noses help us taste yummy things. We're going to be super scientists today and learn all about how our noses work!

slides.setup_instructions: Have jelly beans ready. Set up scented items. Prepare the science journal with experiment headers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to get our experiment stuff ready! We have some colorful jelly beans for tasting, and some special things that smell nice. We also have a special notebook, our science journal, and a pencil to write down what we discover. Can you help mommy or daddy find all these things for our fun?

slides.text: 'Let's do a real experiment! Hold your nose tightly and eat a jelly bean. Can you tell what flavor it is?' (It is very hard without smell!)
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's do our first experiment! Get a jelly bean ready, but first, pinch your nose super tight! Now, take a little bite. Hmm, can you guess what flavor it is when your nose is holding its breath? It's tricky, right?

slides.text: 'Now let go of your nose and take another bite. WOW — the flavor is back! Taste and smell are PARTNERS. Your nose helps you taste!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super fun part! Let go of your nose and take another little bite of the jelly bean. Whoa, can you taste it now? That's because your nose and your tongue are best friends and work together to help you taste all the yummy flavors!

slides.text: 'Experiment 2: Smell these three items. Remember them. Now close your eyes — which one am I holding near you?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is experiment number two! We're going to smell three different things, like maybe cinnamon or lemon. Try to remember what each one smells like. Then, we'll close our eyes, and you'll tell me which smell I'm holding close to your nose!

slides.text: 'Experiment 3: Stand far from this cinnamon stick. Can you smell it? Walk closer. Is the smell stronger? Scent molecules spread through the air!'
slides.mascot_explanation: For our last experiment, we'll try to smell something from far away, like this cinnamon stick. Can you smell it? Now, let's get a little closer... do you smell it even more? That's because smells travel through the air, just like magic!

slides.prompt: In your science journal, write about each experiment: what you did, what happened, and what you learned. Draw a picture of your favorite experiment.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be artists and scientists in our science journal! Let's draw pictures of our favorite experiment and write down what we learned. We can draw the jelly beans or the yummy smells we remembered.

slides.text: 'Your nose works with your tongue to create flavor! Without smell, food has almost no taste. Your senses are all connected.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain that taste and smell work together and demonstrate scent identification from memory?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job being a scientist today! We learned that our noses are super important because they help our tongues taste all the delicious foods. Your nose and tongue are a great team!

parent_notes: The taste-smell connection experiment is genuinely surprising and teaches real neuroscience. What we perceive as 'taste' is actually about 80% smell — that is why food tastes bland when you have a cold. This experiment is memorable and children often share it excitedly with others. The scent intensity experiment introduces a basic concept of diffusion (scent molecules spread through air and become less concentrated with distance). You do not need to use the word diffusion, but the child is experiencing it. Encourage the child to think like a scientist: 'What did we predict? What actually happened? Were we surprised?' This hypothesis-testing mindset is the foundation of scientific thinking.

title: Five Senses Art — A Multi-Sensory Artwork
description: The child creates an artwork that incorporates multiple senses: visual elements, textured surfaces, and scented additions. This culminating art project celebrates the entire five senses exploration.
instructions:
1. 'We have explored all five senses this week! Let's create an artwork that uses AS MANY senses as possible.'
2. Plan: 'What will you create? A garden? An ocean? A kitchen?'
3. Provide multi-sensory materials:
   - Visual: paint, colored paper, markers
   - Texture: sand, fabric, cotton balls, bubble wrap
   - Scent: scratch-and-sniff stickers, or glue + spices (cinnamon, vanilla extract on cotton)
4. The child creates their multi-sensory artwork.
5. Present: 'Tell me about each sense in your artwork.'
materials_needed: Scent materials (spices, extracts, essential oils on cotton)

slides.heading: Multi-Sensory Artwork
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Multi-Sensory Artwork," which means we're going to make a picture that uses lots of our senses, not just our eyes! It's going to be super special.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all materials organized by sense category: visual (paint, markers), touch (sand, fabric, cotton), smell (spices, extracts).
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, friend, let's get our special art supplies ready! We need big paper to draw on, some colorful paint and markers for seeing, fluffy cotton balls and maybe some sand for touching, and we'll even add some yummy smells like cinnamon! Ask your grown-up to help you find all these fun things.

slides.text: 'Today's artwork is special because it will engage more than just your eyes! We are making art you can see, feel, AND smell.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today we're going to make art that's extra special! It's not just for looking at, but we can also *feel* it and even *smell* it. Isn't that exciting? We're going to use all our amazing senses!

slides.text: 'First, plan your picture. What scene will you create? A garden with soft flower petals and cinnamon-scented bark? An ocean with smooth blue fabric waves?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about what kind of picture we want to make. Maybe a sunny garden with soft flower petals and a nice cinnamon smell, or perhaps a blue ocean with bumpy waves you can touch! What do you dream up?

slides.text: 'Use paint and color for the VISUAL parts. Add texture materials for TOUCH. Glue on something scented for SMELL.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When we make our picture, we'll use the paint and markers to make it look pretty for our eyes. Then, we'll glue on things like sand or soft cotton balls so we can feel different textures. And don't forget, we'll add a special smell too!

slides.prompt: Create your multi-sensory artwork. Include at least: 2 visual elements (color/shape), 2 textures (rough/smooth), and 1 scent. Label each sensory element if you can.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make your amazing artwork! You'll use colors to see, add bumpy or smooth things to feel, and a nice smell to smell. Try to make at least two things you can see, two things you can feel, and one thing that smells good. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Your artwork engages three senses at once! Tell me: what can I SEE? What can I FEEL? What can I SMELL? You are a multi-sensory artist!'
slides.mastery_check: Does the artwork intentionally incorporate at least 3 senses (sight, touch, smell) and can the child describe each sensory element?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, look at your wonderful art! It’s so cool because we can SEE the colors, FEEL the different textures like soft cotton or rough sand, and SMELL the yummy cinnamon. You did such a great job making art with so many senses!

parent_notes: This culminating art project synthesizes the entire five senses exploration into a creative expression. The child is not just making art — they are demonstrating their understanding of sensory categories by intentionally incorporating specific senses. The planning phase is important: encourage the child to think about each sense before starting. If the child struggles with what to create, suggest familiar multi-sensory environments: a kitchen (warm colors, rough textures, spice scents), a garden (bright colors, soft petal textures, flower scents), or a beach (blue tones, sandy textures, salty scent). This project makes a beautiful display piece and conversation starter.

title: Hosting the Tea Party — Grace, Courtesy, and Service
description: The child hosts the tea party, welcoming guests, serving food and drinks, facilitating conversation, and managing cleanup. This is the culminating practical life experience that integrates social grace, planning, and independence.
instructions:
1. 'Today is the day! You are the HOST. Let's review what a host does.'
2. Review hosting duties: greet guests at the door, show them to their seats, offer drinks, serve food, make conversation, and clean up.
3. Practice greeting: 'Welcome to my tea party! Please sit here.'
4. The child greets each guest, pours drinks, serves food, and manages the event.
5. Parent supports from the background but lets the child lead.
6. After guests leave, the child cleans up: clear table, wash dishes, wipe surfaces.
7. Reflect: 'How did it go? What was your favorite part? What would you do differently?'

slides.heading: The Tea Party!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look! It says "The Tea Party!" and "You Are the Host." That means today is your special day to have your very own tea party, and you get to be in charge of everything! Isn't that exciting?

slides.setup_instructions: Do a final check: food ready, table set, drinks prepared. Help the child put on their apron and take a deep breath!
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things for our tea party today! We have yummy food and drinks ready to go, and the table is all set up so nicely. We also have a special apron for you to wear, like a real host! Don't forget the cleaning things for after. Now, let's get ready and take a big, happy breath!

slides.text: 'This is YOUR tea party. You planned it, prepared the food, set the table, and now you are the host. I am so proud of you!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is telling you how amazing you are! You worked so hard to plan this tea party, get everything ready, and set the table. Now, you are the boss, the wonderful host, and we are so proud of you for all your hard work!

slides.text: 'When guests arrive: stand, smile, and say Welcome to my tea party! Show them to their seat.'
slides.mascot_explanation: When your friends come to your tea party, stand up tall, give them a big smile, and say, "Welcome to my tea party!" Then, you can show them right where to sit so they feel super comfy.

slides.text: 'Offer drinks: Would you like tea or juice? Pour carefully. Serve the food: Please help yourself! Use your best manners.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be extra kind to your guests! You can ask them if they want tea or juice, and then pour it very carefully for them. After that, you can offer them the yummy food and tell them to please help themselves, using your best manners.

slides.text: 'A good host makes conversation: How is your tea? Would you like more? Thank you for coming!'
slides.mascot_explanation: A super good host like you knows how to talk to their friends! You can ask them if they like their tea or if they want more, and you can even say "Thank you for coming!" to make them feel special.

slides.prompt: Host your entire tea party from greeting to goodbye. Serve, converse, and make your guests feel welcome. After they leave, clean up completely.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part! Now you get to have your whole tea party! You'll welcome your friends, give them drinks and food, and talk with them. When everyone goes home, you get to be a super helper and clean up all by yourself!

slides.text: 'You hosted a real tea party all by yourself — from planning to cleanup! How does it feel? What was the best part? You are a wonderful host.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently greet guests, serve food and drinks, maintain conversation, and clean up with minimal adult intervention?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You hosted a whole tea party, all by yourself, from the very beginning to the very end! How does that feel? What was your very favorite thing you did today? You are such a wonderful and amazing host!

parent_notes: This is one of the most significant practical life experiences in the Montessori primary curriculum. The child has spent an entire week planning, preparing, and now executing a social event. Every step required real skills: writing (invitations), math (counting settings), cooking, table setting, grace and courtesy, and now social leadership. Resist the urge to take over — even if the tea spills or the cookies are uneven, this is the child's event. Your role is background support: refill the kettle, help with a stubborn lid, prompt gently if needed. The cleanup is equally important — a Montessori host sees the work through to completion. Document this with photos; it is a milestone worth remembering.

title: Descriptive Writing — Using All Five Senses
description: The child writes a descriptive paragraph using sensory language, incorporating details from all five senses. This synthesizes the week's science theme with the child's growing writing abilities.
instructions:
1. 'Great writers describe things so well that readers can see, hear, smell, taste, and feel what they are writing about. Let's try!'
2. Choose a topic together: the tea party, a favorite place, a season, or a meal.
3. Brainstorm sensory details for each sense:
   - Sight: What colors, shapes, movements?
   - Sound: What sounds?
   - Smell: What scents?
   - Taste: What flavors?
   - Touch: What textures or temperatures?
4. Write 4-6 sentences using sensory words.
5. Read aloud: 'Can I picture what you described?'
materials_needed: Sensory brainstorm sheet (5 sections, one per sense)
Sensory word bank (posted or on a card)

slides.heading: Descriptive Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Descriptive Writing," and that means we get to be super storytellers! We're going to learn how to use our special words so that when we write, our friends can imagine they are right there with us, using all their senses.

slides.setup_instructions: Create a brainstorm sheet with 5 sections labeled: I see..., I hear..., I smell..., I taste..., I feel... Provide a word bank of sensory adjectives.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to get our tools ready for writing fun! We have a special paper called a "brainstorm sheet" to write down our ideas, some lined paper for our story, and a pencil to write with. We also have a "sensory word bank" to help us find super descriptive words and colorful pencils to make a picture!

slides.text: 'The best writers make their readers FEEL like they are there. They describe what they see, hear, smell, taste, and touch!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is so important for being a great writer! When we use words that tell us what things look like, sound like, smell like, taste like, and feel like, our readers can really imagine everything. It's like magic for their ears and noses and eyes!

slides.text: 'Let's write about the tea party (or another topic you choose). First, fill in the brainstorm sheet: What did you SEE? HEAR? SMELL?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's pick something fun to write about, like our pretend tea party! We'll use our brainstorm sheet to think about what we saw, like the pretty teacups, what we heard, like giggling, and what we smelled, like yummy cookies.

slides.text: 'Now use your brainstorm words to write sentences. Try to include at least one detail for each sense.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to turn our ideas into sentences! We'll look at the words we wrote on our brainstorm sheet and try to put them into our story. Let's try to tell everyone what we saw, heard, smelled, tasted, and felt.

slides.prompt: Write 4-6 sentences describing your topic using all five senses. Use words from your brainstorm sheet. Draw a picture to go with your writing.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to write our amazing story! We'll write about 4 to 6 sentences using all the wonderful sensory words we thought of. Then, we'll draw a beautiful picture to show everyone what our story is all about.

slides.text: 'Read your writing to me. I can almost see, hear, and smell what you described! Sensory details make writing come alive.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child produce a descriptive paragraph that includes sensory details from at least 3 of 5 senses?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Let's read your story. Wow, I can almost see the sparkly teacups and smell the sweet cookies – your words made it feel so real! You used so many wonderful sensory details, and that makes your writing super special.

parent_notes: Descriptive writing using sensory details is a natural culmination of both the five senses science unit and the child's developing writing skills. The brainstorm sheet is essential scaffolding — it separates the thinking from the writing, so the child is not overwhelmed. The sensory word bank provides vocabulary support. If the child writes about the tea party, the details will be vivid because the experience is fresh and personal: 'The tea was warm. The cookies crunched. I smelled cinnamon.' This is real, meaningful writing born from real experience — exactly what Montessori education aims for. Accept invented spelling and celebrate the content. This piece belongs in the child's writing portfolio.

title: Telling Time — Daily Schedule Math
description: The child creates a daily schedule using analog clock times and calculates how long activities take. This practical application of time-telling connects math to daily life and builds number sense around duration.
instructions:
1. 'Let's use our time-telling skills to plan a day! What time do you wake up?'
2. The child sets the clock to their wake-up time. Write it on the schedule.
3. Continue through the day: breakfast, lessons, lunch, play, dinner, bedtime.
4. 'How long is breakfast? If you start at 7:30 and finish at 8:00, that is 30 minutes!'
5. Calculate duration for 3-4 activities.
6. Draw clock faces next to each activity showing the correct time.
7. 'You planned your whole day using math!'
materials_needed: Daily schedule template (time, activity, duration columns)

slides.heading: My Daily Schedule
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "My Daily Schedule." That means we get to make a plan for our whole day, just like grown-ups do, and we'll use our super-duper time-telling skills!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a schedule template with columns: Time, Activity, How Long. Have the demonstration clock ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our schedule, we need some special tools! We have a pretend clock to show the times, a paper to draw on, and pencils to write and color with. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these things so we can start our fun?

slides.text: 'We have been practicing telling time. Now let's USE it! We are going to plan your day with exact times.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We've learned all about telling time, haven't we? Now, we get to be clock detectives and use what we know to plan out *your* whole day, from when you wake up until you go to sleep!

slides.text: 'What time do you wake up? Set it on the clock. Write it on your schedule. What do you do next? What time?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's think about when you wake up in the morning. Can you show me that time on our pretend clock? Then, we'll write it down on our paper, and we can think about what you do next and what time that happens!

slides.text: 'Now let's figure out HOW LONG each activity takes. If breakfast starts at 7:30 and ends at 8:00, count by 5s: 35, 40, 45, 50, 55, 60. That is 30 minutes!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's figure out how long things take. If breakfast starts when the big hand is on the 12 and ends when it's on the 6, we can count all the little numbers to see how much time passed! It's like counting how many yummy bites you took.

slides.text: 'Draw a little clock face next to each activity showing the start time. This is YOUR daily schedule!'
slides.mascot_explanation: For each thing we write down, like playing or eating lunch, we get to draw a little clock face right next to it. This shows everyone exactly what time that fun thing happens! It’s like drawing a picture of the time.

slides.prompt: Complete your daily schedule from waking to bedtime. Include at least 8 activities with times. Calculate how long at least 3 activities take.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be the boss of your day! Let's fill in everything you do, from waking up to bedtime, and count how long some of your favorite things take. You get to decide what your amazing day looks like!

slides.text: 'You used time-telling, counting, and subtraction to plan your day! Math is everywhere in real life — especially in telling time.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a realistic daily schedule with correct analog times and calculate duration for at least 2 activities?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You planned your whole day using times and counting, just like a super smart mathematician! You showed how time helps us know when to play and when to eat, and that's pretty amazing!

parent_notes: Creating a daily schedule is a beautiful integration of time-telling with real life. It also develops executive function — the ability to plan, sequence, and manage time. Calculating duration is essentially subtraction on a clock, which is more complex than it seems because the clock is base-60, not base-10. At this age, keep durations simple: 30 minutes, 1 hour, 15 minutes. If the child notices that the same activities happen at the same times each day, that is a discovery about routine and rhythm — both important Montessori concepts. You can laminate this schedule and use it daily, which reinforces both time-telling and the child's sense of autonomy.

title: Gratitude and Reflection — Looking Back at Our Learning
description: The child reflects on everything they have learned during this week and throughout the year, creating a gratitude list and discussing their growth. This builds self-awareness and emotional intelligence.
instructions:
1. 'We have had an amazing week! Let's think about everything we learned and everything we are grateful for.'
2. Review the week together: tea party, five senses, research report, multiplication.
3. 'What are you most proud of this week?'
4. Create a gratitude list: 'What are 5 things you are thankful for in your learning?'
5. 'Think about the beginning of the year. What could you NOT do then that you CAN do now?'
6. The child draws a before-and-after: 'Me at the beginning of the year / Me now.'
7. Celebrate growth: 'Look how much you have grown!'
materials_needed: Photos from earlier in the year (optional)

slides.heading: Gratitude and Reflection
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun slide! It says "Gratitude and Reflection" and "Celebrating Our Growth." That means we get to think about all the amazing things we did this week and how much smarter we're getting, like a superhero getting stronger!

slides.setup_instructions: Divide drawing paper in half: label one side 'Beginning of the Year' and the other 'Now.' Prepare list paper for gratitude.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need some special things for our activity! We need drawing paper to make pictures, colored pencils to make them bright, and some list paper to write on. If you have old photos, they can help us remember! Ask a grown-up to help you find these.

slides.text: 'What an incredible week! You hosted a tea party, explored all five senses, wrote a research report, and learned new math. Let's celebrate!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We had such a super fun week, didn't we? We had a pretend tea party, we used our noses and ears and eyes to learn, we wrote a special report, and we even learned some new numbers! Let's think about all those cool things.

slides.text: 'What are you MOST proud of? There is no wrong answer — maybe it is the tea party, or a math fact you memorized, or your poem.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about what made you feel super happy and proud this week. Maybe it was sharing your toys, or learning a new song, or building a tall tower! What was the very best thing that made your heart feel sunny?

slides.text: 'Let's make a gratitude list: 5 things you are thankful for about learning. It could be a book, a material, a person, or something you can do now.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's make a special list of things we feel thankful for when we learn. Maybe you're thankful for a storybook that you love, or for your teacher, or for being able to draw a picture now! We need to think of five things that make learning feel good.

slides.text: 'Now draw two pictures: YOU at the beginning of the year, and YOU now. What has changed? What can you do now that you could not do then?'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to draw two pictures of you! On one side, draw yourself at the very beginning of school, and on the other side, draw yourself right now. Think about all the new things you can do now that you couldn't do before!

slides.prompt: Write your gratitude list (5 items). Draw your before-and-after pictures. Share them with your family.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to do all the fun things we talked about! We'll write down the five things we're thankful for, draw our two pictures of you growing, and then we can show our family how amazing we are. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You have grown so much! Every lesson, every practice, every challenge made you stronger and smarter. I am so proud of who you are becoming.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child articulate at least 3 specific areas of growth and express gratitude for their learning journey?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at you! You have grown so much, like a little seed growing into a big flower! All the learning and trying new things made you so smart and strong. I'm so happy to see how wonderful you are becoming!

parent_notes: Reflection and gratitude are essential components of Montessori peace education. When children articulate their growth, they develop a growth mindset — the understanding that abilities are developed through effort, not fixed at birth. The before-and-after drawing is powerfully visual: a child who could not read in September can now write research reports. A child who cried over separation can now host a tea party. Name these growth areas specifically: 'Remember when you did not know any letter sounds? Now you READ BOOKS!' This is not empty praise — it is factual observation of real growth, which is deeply motivating. Save this reflection piece in the child's portfolio.

title: Read-Aloud: Amazing Grace by Mary Hoffman
description: The story of Grace, who loves stories and acting, and is told she cannot play Peter Pan because she is a girl and Black. With her family's encouragement, she auditions and proves that she can be anything she wants to be.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is Grace. She LOVES stories. She acts out every story she hears. Let's see what happens.'
2. Read aloud with expression, enjoying Grace's dramatic re-enactments.
3. When classmates say she cannot play Peter Pan: 'How do you think Grace feels? What would you say?'
4. Grace's grandmother takes her to see a Black ballerina. 'What does Grace learn from this?'
5. Grace auditions and wins the role. 'What helped Grace succeed?'
6. Discuss: 'Is there anything you have been told you cannot do? What did Grace's story teach you?'

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we're going to read a story called "Amazing Grace"! It's about a girl named Grace who really, really loves stories and pretending. Let's find out what happens to her in this story!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up reading area. This book benefits from a quiet, focused reading environment.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need our special book for our story time today! It's right here, the book called "Amazing Grace." We'll find a cozy spot so we can listen carefully and enjoy the story together.

slides.text: 'Grace loves stories more than anything! She acts out every story she hears. Watch as we read — she plays ALL the characters!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part tells us that Grace loves stories so much! She pretends to be all the characters when she hears them. Let's listen to our story and see how she acts everything out!

slides.text: Read with expression. When Grace acts out stories, be dramatic! When the classmates are unkind, pause.
slides.mascot_explanation: When we read, we'll use our best voices to show how Grace feels! We'll be super excited when she's pretending and be extra quiet when something sad happens.

slides.text: 'Grace's classmates said she could not play Peter Pan. Her grandmother said she could be anything she wanted if she put her mind to it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh no! Some friends told Grace she couldn't be Peter Pan because she's a girl and she's Black. But her grandma told her she can be anything she dreams of!

slides.prompt: Discuss: What does 'you can be anything you want' mean? Is there something you dream of being? Draw yourself achieving a big dream.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about what "being anything you want" means. What is something super cool that you dream of being when you grow up? Let's draw a picture of you doing that big dream!

slides.text: 'Grace proved that with practice, determination, and belief in yourself, you can do amazing things. YOU can too. What is your dream?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the story's theme (believing in yourself despite others' doubts) and connect it to their own aspirations?
slides.mascot_explanation: Grace learned that if you believe in yourself and try hard, you can do amazing things, even if people say you can't! What amazing dream do you have in your heart?

parent_notes: Amazing Grace is a powerful book about self-belief, representation, and the transformative power of stories. It addresses race and gender stereotypes at an age-appropriate level, showing how family support and personal determination can overcome limiting beliefs. The grandmother's response — taking Grace to see a Black ballerina rather than just telling her she can be anything — models the Montessori principle that concrete experience is more powerful than abstract instruction. After reading, if your child shares a dream or aspiration, take it seriously and explore it: 'You want to be a marine biologist? Let's learn more about what they do!' This validates the child's identity and ambitions.
